whipplei is excreted in a live form by patients with Whipple disease (9), and T. whipplei DNA is found in stool samples of healthy persons (22) this bacterium is commonly found in sewers (20,23) and has also been detected in sewage (25). serologic analysis by Western blotting for T. whipplei (29) showed that all children who were PCR positive for T. whipplei had IgM against T. whipplei. the prevalence of antibodies in case-patients was higher than that in controls. this may explain why this bacterium causes diarrhea in children. we identified 1 clone (genotype 3) in 10 children. this indicates that this clone is circulating in our population. however, for unknown reasons, T. whipplei could replicate in children with low-grade chronic infections without causing diarrhea.
